title: Cicero Brutus 3 - we learn from lines 9-12

content.description:
Directions: Read the following selection carefully for comprehension. The selection is followed by a number of related questions and incomplete statements. Select the best answer or completion.

Cicero recalls an encounter with Brutus and Atticus.

Nam cum inambularem in xysto1 et essem otiosus2

domi, ad me Brutus, ut consueverat, cum Attico venit,

homines cum3 inter se coniuncti tum mihi ita cari

itaque iucundi, ut eorum aspectu omnis quae me

(5) angebat4 de re publica cura consederit. Quos postquam

salutavi: “Quid vos,” inquam, “Brute et Attice?”

“Numquid5 tandem novi?" “Nihil sane, »6 inquit

Brutus, “quod quidem aut tu audire velis aut ego pro

certo dicere audeam." Tum Atticus: “Eo,” inquit, “ad

(10) te animo venimus, ut de re publicā esset silentium et

aliquid audiremus potius ex te quam te afficeremus

ullā molestiā." “Vos vero,” inquam, “et praesentem me

curā levatis et absenti magna solacia dedistis. Nam

vestris primum litteris recreatus me ad pristina7 studia

revocavi.”

1 xystus, -i, m.: colonnade

2 otiosus, -a, -um: at leisure

3 cum ... tum: both. . .and

4 ango, -ere: distress

5 Numquid: (introduces a question) “Is there anything. . .?”

6 sane: surely

7 pristinus, -a, -um: former
content.question: We Iearn from the words “Eo . . . molestia” (lines 9-12) that Atticus and Brutus

choices.label: want to get Cicero’s advice on legal matters
had heard that some people had recently annoyed Cicero
have not come to upset Cicero with political discussion
were annoyed that some politicians had not spoken on behalf of the republic

content.answer: have not come to upset Cicero with political discussion
